metadata.case_name: Kanti Prasad Jayshankar Yagnik v. Purshottamdass Ranchoddas Patel

facts.text: Poll for election to Gujarat State Assembly from Mehsana Constituency taken on February 21, 1967, result declared on February 22, 1967.
Appellant (Kanti Prasad Jayshankar Yagnik) secured 23,055 votes, petitioner (Purshottamdass Ranchoddas Patel) secured 16,159 votes, other candidates secured 720, 1,017 and 454 votes.
Election petition filed on April 5, 1967, praying for declaration of appellant's election void and petitioner duly elected.
Appellant and agents arranged public meetings of Shambhu Maharaj on February 18, 1967, at villages in Mehsana Constituency including Motidav, Kherwa, Dangerwa.

Shambhu Maharaj made speeches appealing to vote for appellant on grounds of religion, caste, community; stated voting for Congress (petitioner) irreligious as it allowed slaughter of cows and bullocks; used undue influence by inducing belief in divine displeasure.
Petitioner proved speeches via police witnesses who recorded notes under government instructions; High Court relied on reports as correctly recorded.
High Court discarded testimony of petitioner's witnesses PW 25 to 33 as not corroborated by independent witnesses.
Appellant present at meetings as per police witnesses; tour programme arranged by appellant with Maganlal A. Patel to aid election.
Gujarat High Court by judgment dated December 5, 1967 set aside appellant's election under ss. 123(2), 123(3), 100(1)(b) of RP Act 1951.

legal_issues.text: Whether police reports of Shambhu Maharaj's speeches are admissible under ss. 159, 160, 161 of Indian Evidence Act.
Whether speeches by Shambhu Maharaj amount to corrupt practices under ss. 123(2) and 123(3) of Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Whether appellant consented to the speeches constituting corrupt practices.
What weight to attach to police reports of speeches.

petitioner_arguments.text: Speeches by Shambhu Maharaj with appellant's consent appealed to electors on ground of religion, caste, community; voting for Congress irreligious due to cow/bullock slaughter; undue influence via threats of divine displeasure/spiritual censure.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: ss. 123(2), 123(3), 100(1)(b) of Representation of the People Act, 1951

respondent_arguments.text: Police reports inadmissible under Indian Evidence Act as not used to refresh memory under s.159 or satisfying s.160 conditions; no specific recollection stated; little weight due to notes not shorthand.
No consent by appellant to speeches proved.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 123 Representation of the People Act, 1951

respondent_arguments.text: Speeches do not constitute corrupt practices; no appeal on candidate's religion/caste; no proof of Jagadguru's influence.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: ss. 123(2), 123(3) Representation of the People Act, 1951

court_reasoning.text: Police reports admissible under s.160 Evidence Act as written by witnesses contemporaneously or soon after; conditions impliedly satisfied despite no express statement; weight to be considered separately.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Witnesses testified after 9 months; notes made during speeches; reports part of oral evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Reports credible due to common topics, language, approach across multiple constables at different times/places; substance correctly reproduced even if not verbatim.
In Ex.J (Motidav): Passage 3 not corrupt under s.123(3) as no proof Jagadguru influenced majority voters; appeal in name of religion not barred unless on candidate's religion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishable from Ram Dial v. Sant Lal.

court_reasoning.text: In Ex.K (Kherwa): Passages 1-2 not corrupt under s.123(2) as no direct causal link to divine displeasure via cow slaughter; Passage 3 appeal to religion fondness ok; Passage 4 corrupt under s.123(3) as appeal to vote for appellant as Brahmin minister.
In Ex.P (Dangerwa): Passages 1 and 3 together induce belief in divine displeasure if vote Congress due to cow slaughter; constitutes s.123(2) corrupt practice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Exploits belief in cow holiness and gohatya sin.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant's consent proved: arranged tour programme; present at meetings; did not dissociate; to aid his election.

holdings.text: Police reports admissible and credible under Evidence Act ss.159-161.
Specific speeches in Ex.K (passage 4) and Ex.P (passages 1,3) constitute corrupt practices under ss.123(3) and 123(2) RP Act.
Hegde J. concurs on Ex.P as s.123(2); dissents on need for speaker's influence over majority; dissents on Ex.K passage 4 as not caste appeal.

precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished as there Sat Guru had local influence among voters unlike Jagadguru here.
Cow venerated; gohatya sin leads to divine displeasure/spiritual censure.
Dissent on constable notes proving impression not words.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohansingh Laxmansingh v. Bhanwarlal Rajmal Nahata
precedents_cited.relevance: Held notes not primary evidence if suspicion of inaccuracy.
Requires express statement of no recollection and correctness.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Appeal under s.116A; corrupt practices of undue influence s.123(2), appeal on religion/caste/community s.123(3); grounds for void election s.100(1)(b).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Admissibility of police reports to refresh memory or testify to recorded facts.

outcome.summary: Appeal against Gujarat High Court order setting aside appellant's election dismissed; corrupt practices under ss.123(2) and 123(3) RP Act committed with appellant's consent.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court order upheld; appellant's election void.

key_quotes.text: "Do not vote for the Congress and by putting the mark of vote on the symbol of bullocks amounts to cutting the throat of a bullock by a knife symbolized by your vote."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Example of speech in Ex.J not held corrupt.

key_quotes.text: "We must have at least one minister who is a Brahmin. Hence vote for Kantilalbhai."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Held corrupt under s.123(3) as caste appeal.

key_quotes.text: "Every day twenty four crores of cows are being slaughtered, then how God will tolerate that and how will you get happiness?"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Induces belief in divine displeasure if vote Congress; s.123(2).

key_quotes.text: "It is not necessary that before a statement can be considered as an attempt to induce an elector to believe that he will be rendered an object of spiritual censure... that statement must have been made by a person who is a religious head of the majority."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Hegde J. separate opinion broadening s.123(2).
